positions.title: Research Scientist
positions.description:
• Led development of Passage, a C/OpenMP code generator for hierarchical Bayesian modeling, written in Haskell.
• Led research and development of parallel coordinate descent algorithms for sparse (ℓ1-regularized) classification; published in top-tier international machine learning conferences (ICML, NIPS).
• Designed a statistical model for location estimation of a radiological source. Implemented model fitting using expectation maximization (EM algorithm) and Haskell regular parallel arrays (repa).
• Designed statistical models for a wide variety of domains, including radiation detection, proteomics, data compression, and network anomaly detection.
• Designed and implemented parallel algorithms for statistical learning and other scientific applications.

given.text:
The Metis Data Science Bootcamp was a life changing experience for me, mainly due to the quality of the Metis staff. Chad was one of two instructors for my cohort. He taught lessons in the mornings and helped us work through projects in the afternoons for an intensive 12 week bootcamp. One Monday morning after a weekend of puzzling through some aspects of a project I asked Chad for help. He said I should look at a Bayesian pymc3 model, then proceeded to help me understand and implement the model in the next few days. I was exhilarated by the Bayesian methods and grateful for the coaching I received from Chad. He had a way of understanding the rabbit holes we students were going down and an exceptional depth of knowledge combined with a true caring for others that helped us grow to be better data scientists. I am grateful to have had Chad as an instructor.

The key to technical teaching in an intensive and immersive environment is do be clear, effective, and supportive. Chad is the heart of the classroom. He hit the ground running working along side a seasoned instructor and always spoke up when things didn't make sense or he had something to contribute. In a startup environment we all had to take on multiple roles and Chad always and immediately stepped up to handle any extra time in the classroom without a complaint and always with his signature smile. The best part about working with Chad is his thoughtful approach with the students. He carefully deliberated over the feedback he provided, especially in written form, to ensure that he maximized constructive ideas and inclusiveness. Of all the instructors he was among the few who was open and willing to talk through situations with students and come up with the best approach for both the individual and the community. Chad as a team mate is awesome. He always has a laugh or a smile and an encouraging word and has quickly become one of the best things about being at Metis.

Chad is an extremely capable researcher and has proven an invaluable mathematical resource. We worked together chiefly on the implementation of a scheme for localization of radiological sources by drawing inference from data taken from spatially distributed detectors. Chad's knowledge, both of the necessary numerical techniques and of the parallel code for the generation of results, has been exemplary. In addition, his commitment to the careful production and validation of results adds a great deal of rigor and confidence in the numerical modeling arena.

Chad consistently displays outstanding technical scientific knowledge and practice, and combines that with a desire to always understand the significance of the application and problem space, guiding his technical work to results that matter to clients. He consistently improves the quality of mathematical modeling and analysis in research projects, providing a level of rigor that makes our results more defensible. For example, as part of an effort to study the viability of monitoring containerized cargo for illicit radiological sources during oceanic transit, Chad established the statistical foundation for estimating radiological content of containers, a component that was crucial to the effort's success. He is highly adaptable to new challenges and always eager to learn new concepts, functions well independently as well as collaboratively, seeking and welcoming input and sharing the credit. It has been a thorough pleasure for me to work with Chad.

I've worked with Chad on the development of a DSL for Bayesian Modeling in Haskell. Chad demonstrated a deep understanding of both the complicated mathematics involved, and the language development aspects; including the design of a high-performance, massively parallel code generator, starting from very high-level specifications. Chad is joy to work with, and is a clear asset to any team.

Chad was always happy to work hard, find creative solutions, and strive to disseminate those solutions in the form of papers. received.text:
I taught and mentored Dana in data science during her time at Metis.

Dana has a natural curiosity and a rigorous analytical background; her management experience gives her a keen business sense, and the self-discipline to make the hard decisions needed to stay on track and deliver on time. She will be a great asset to any data science team.

I was Jhonsen's instructor at Metis.

Jhonsen works hard, delivering solid analytical results and engaging presentations. During the bootcamp, Jhonsen quickly became very involved in the Metis community, and has remained so since his graduation. He was also very active on the bootcamp cohort's Slack channel, frequently offering technical references, as well as general encouragement and team-building.

I believe Jhonsen has a bright career path ahead of him. As a Junior Data Scientist (for now), he would be a valuable asset to any team.
